results.title: Mineral exploration
results.brief_description: Shows the modern prospecting team of geologist, geophysicist and geochemist searching for and investigating the extent of Australia’s mineral resources. Shows geophysicists searching for extension of tin and lead ore bodies at Zeehan, measuring the electrical potential of the earth at the surface; conducting a seismic survey, re-examining old mining fields, drilling, using a geiger counter for aerial photographs to prepare base maps etc.

results.title: Mineral deficiencies: copper and cobalt
results.brief_description: Science aids wool series, no. 7. This film shows the harmful effects of a deficiency of copper and cobalt in the soil in the south-eastern coastal areas of South Australia, and in certain areas in other states.

results.title: Miner
results.creator_credit: Robin Spry, John Kemeny and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Impressions of a hardrock miner’s life, suitable for the classroom, filmed at the Falconbridge Nickel Mine at Sudbury, Ontario, and showing also the increasing use of nickel in today’s space age. Much of what is shown was filmed in the dim world far underground where, “in a bubble of air in a solid mass of rock,” the miner drills the ore face.

results.title: Minecraft
results.brief_description: Minecraft is an open world game that has no specific goals for the player to accomplish, allowing players a large amount of freedom in choosing how to play the game however, there is an achievement system. The gameplay by default is first person, but players have the option to play in third person mode. The core gameplay revolves around breaking and placing blocks. The game world is essentially composed of rough 3D objects—mainly cubes—that are arranged in a fixed grid pattern and represent different materials, such as dirt, stone, various ores, water, and tree trunks. While players can move freely across the world, objects and items can only be placed at fixed locations relative to the grid. Players can gather these material blocks and place them elsewhere, thus allowing for various constructions.

constellations_other.name: New ways of seeing
constellations_other.description: The 3D worlds presented through the stereoscopic viewer are part of an ongoing fascination with immersive imagery.

results.title: Mine shaft sinking
results.brief_description: Describes the construction of the new shafts in a pit producing the best anthracite in the world, near Llanelly, in South Wales. First the removal of the soil and rock is shown, then the blasting to penetrate the bedrock. The ventilation of the shaft is also demonstrated, followed by the concreting of the shaft. Stresses that the job scheduled for 104 weeks was in fact completed in 74.

results.title: Mine on Channel Reef
results.creator_credit: Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of Defence
results.brief_description: Two divers swimming near Channel Reef, a coral reef off the coast of Cairns in Queensland, come across a live mine. The Royal Australian Navy locate and dispose of the mine.

results.title: Mindscape
results.creator_credit: Jacques Drouin, Gaston Sarault and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A particularly creative example of the pinscreen animation technique, this film is about an artist who steps inside his painting and wanders about in a landscape peopled with symbols that trigger unexpected associations. Film without words. (Eighteen awards including Ottawa; Yorkton; Columbus; New York; Los Angeles)

results.title: Mind your back
results.creator_credit: Bruce Bennett, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The proper method of lifting heavy loads in coal mines. Demonstrates correct and incorrect methods in a variety of circumstrances, including raising, carrying and lowering a load; lifting, pushing and pulling a prop; lifting a gas cylinder, bag of cement, and 44 gallon drum; and team lifting.

results.title: Mind-slaughter
results.brief_description: A look at the atmosphere of the earth and other planets as oceans of gases providing planetary life-support systems, and the consequences of an experiment to create an atmosphere for human habitation on another planet at the cost of existing life forms. Dramatically presented but fascinating comparative analysis, nonetheless, of earth and venus’s atmosphere - with a view to human habitation on the latter. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Mind's eye
results.creator_credit: Brandon Tomlin and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: For years, I have been compiling images in my mind’s eye, while passing through the laneways of Richmond, to the neon lights of Melbourne. Despite having cerebral palsy, Brandon Tomlin lives independently and spends his time taking photos of Melbourne and surrounding suburbs. This is a compilation of some of his work.
